Yes! Calligraphy is still widely practiced and valued today, although its popularity varies across different cultures and regions. In some cultures, calligraphy has maintained a strong tradition and is still considered a crucial part of their cultural identity, while in other places, it has become less prominent.

In East Asia, calligraphy remains an essential cultural practice and is still taught in schools. Many people practice calligraphy as a hobby and attend calligraphy exhibitions and competitions.

In Islamic cultures, calligraphy is widely used for religious and artistic purposes. It remains an important tool for writing the Quran and other religious texts, and it is also used for creating beautiful art pieces, such as murals and paintings.

In Western cultures, calligraphy has gained popularity as a hobby and an art form. Many individuals attend calligraphy classes or workshops to learn the art of beautiful writing. Calligraphy is now used to create wedding invitations, greeting cards, and other personalized items.

Overall, calligraphy remains an important and valued practice across many cultures, and it continues to be appreciated for its artistic beauty and cultural significance.
